title: Addicted to the Ideal: Perfectionism
description: This article explores perfectionism, emphasizing that striving for high standards can be helpful, but when it turns into rigid demands, it leads to negative consequences such as anxiety and chronic dissatisfaction. Real-life examples show how early experiences and upbringing can contribute to the development of perfectionistic beliefs and behaviors. The article concludes with an invitation to find a balance between aiming for excellence and accepting a "good enough" result in order to avoid burnout and disappointment.

texts: Wanting to reach high standards, do things well, and be productive can be a very positive quality.
The same goes for wishing to be accepted, appreciated, loved, or to have meaningful achievements in life.
When these stay at the level of wishes, aspirations, and goals, we can talk about constructive beliefs that support us and motivate us.
But when these wishes turn into rigid, inflexible demands, and the price of meeting them becomes too high, this is no longer just about high standards — it is perfectionism.
What does it mean to be a perfectionist?
Perfectionism — the belief that everything has to be done 100% perfectly — often lies at the root of many difficulties.
You strive for an ideal: mistakes feel unacceptable, and any failure seems like a catastrophe. You may feel that you must look, feel, think, and behave flawlessly in every situation.

As soon as you reach one goal, it is instantly replaced by another, even more distant one, so you never really feel satisfaction or recognition for your efforts. Life turns into a gray, exhausting routine, because you live trying to match unrealistic and sometimes impossible standards.
In other words, a perfectionist tends to:
constantly compare themselves to other people,
live in a state of ongoing competition,
focus on failures and setbacks while overlooking successes,
harshly criticize themselves or others,
struggle to adapt to real-life circumstances,
keep postponing tasks and procrastinating.

quote.text: Perfectionism is just fear in expensive shoes and a mink coat, pretending to be elegant when it’s really just terrified underneath.
quote.author: Elizabeth Gilbert

texts: A model of perfectionism in practice

According to cognitive behavioral therapy, our life experience shapes our core beliefs about ourselves, other people, and the world. These beliefs, in turn, drive the rules and strategies we follow in everyday life.
Let’s take Eugene as an example. His parents always set very high expectations for him: any grade below “excellent” was treated as a failure.
Even though he was clearly gifted in music, his parents criticized his achievements and pushed him toward a more “prestigious” career in medicine.
This experience led Eugene to develop a deep belief that he is “not good enough” and “not competent”.
To compensate for this and to feel like a good, capable person, he adopted a rule: “I must do everything perfectly.”

His drive for perfection pushes him to overwork, scold himself for the smallest mistakes, and be highly critical of his colleagues. This leads to exhaustion, anxiety, relationship problems, and dissatisfaction with life.
He often sets unrealistic goals for himself — for instance, preparing a flawless presentation in very limited time.

If he manages to do this (which is unlikely), his rule is reinforced and gives him an illusion of control. If he does not succeed, he blames himself, which further confirms his belief in his own incompetence.

It becomes a vicious circle: the rule “do everything perfectly” protects Eugene from painful feelings of “not being enough”, but only as long as he can keep up with his excessively high, unrealistic standards.
Any mistake triggers intense negative emotions, fuels his self-criticism, and strengthens perfectionism.
What might perfectionistic beliefs sound like?
I have to do everything perfectly.
Everything I do has to work out.
If I don’t give 100%, I might as well not do it at all.
If someone criticizes me, it means I did a bad job. Doing a bad job is unacceptable.
I am not allowed to make mistakes.
I must be the best at everything I do.
How does this constant drive for an ideal develop?
Most often, this tendency starts in early childhood or primary school as a result of family upbringing.

Researchers believe that neurotic perfectionism develops under the influence of childhood experiences with parents who either showed love only under certain conditions (for grades, results, achievements, etc.) or did not show approval at all.

In both cases, the child develops a strong wish to be perfect in order to prove to their parents — and to themselves — that they can be good and worthy. Parents of perfectionistic children often criticize a lot, withhold support, and have very high demands.
To meet their expectations and avoid punishment or criticism, the child feels forced to try to be flawless.
In general, there are four types of parental behavior that can contribute to the development of perfectionism:
Parents themselves model highly perfectionistic behavior.
Parents are overly critical and demanding toward the child, and emotional support and help are lacking.
Parental approval is absent, inconsistent, or strictly conditional.
Parenting is authoritarian, with excessive expectations and rigid control.
Starting school encourages children to translate their success into grades.

This is where the “straight-A student” pattern often develops, which psychologists link to perfectionism. The child tries to be the best at everything, and if this does not work out, polarized “all-or-nothing” thinking is activated.
If it is impossible to be the best in a particular subject, the child may choose the opposite strategy — to become the worst — as if thinking, “If I can’t be first, I might as well be last.”

Beyond family influences, perfectionism is also encouraged by modern society. At school and university, teachers often favor compliant high achievers, and employers tend to value perfectionistic employees.
A market-driven culture pushes people toward competition and a constant race for better and better results.

The media sets trends and standards of beauty and success. Looking good, dressing stylishly, and taking care of your appearance are portrayed as conditions for finding a partner, getting a prestigious job, and having an attractive social circle.
Because of this, people can become convinced that they must live up to very high standards in order to belong.
So is perfectionism good or bad?
This question often sparks debate: some see perfectionism as helpful, others as harmful.

If you are a perfectionist, you will probably say that striving for perfection is normal — how else could you achieve success? But in reality, perfectionism drains a huge amount of your energy and resources, slowly but relentlessly exhausting both body and mind.
Perfectionism is closely linked to achievement dependence, which we discussed in previous chapters, and its drawbacks are very similar.
Excessive, unrealistic standards affect almost every area of life: work, studies, relationships, and even rest.
The core problem is that the ideal you are chasing simply does not exist. An ideal is a hypothetical, “perfect” state of an object or phenomenon — and everyone imagines it differently.
Let’s be honest and ask: is there anything that is absolutely perfect for everyone?
What you see as ideal may seem completely meaningless to someone else. Even Mozart’s music and da Vinci’s paintings are not universally loved, despite being considered masterpieces.
When you adjust your beliefs to be more in line with reality, you will be able to feel satisfaction with what you have done and with your life in general, rather than constant disappointment.
It is crucial to learn how to balance striving for the best with being satisfied with a good, workable result.

exercise.title: What to do if you have perfectionism, no ideal, but want to live normally?
exercise.description: The article examines two types of perfectionism - negative and positive, offering effective recommendations for dealing with perfectionist tendencies. The author presents eight key strategies, including motivation for change, cognitive restructuring, process orientation instead of result orientation, and formation of new, healthier beliefs. The main idea is that perfectionism can be overcome by learning to accept imperfection, love oneself unconditionally, and take care of oneself daily.

texts: Modern scientists distinguish two types of perfectionism: negative and positive, or in other words, healthy and pathological.
To turn a minus into a plus, it's important to combine your leadership qualities and striving for perfection with common sense and rationality.
We have prepared effective recommendations for working with perfectionism for you.
The best starting point for tackling any problem is motivation for change.
To overcome perfectionism, it's important to understand why you need it. Analyze and write down all the pros and cons.
You might be surprised to find that there are many more difficulties than advantages. Once you realize and accept this, it will be much easier for you to change.
Like many people, you probably think that everything should be done 100% or that mistakes should never be made, or you adhere to other similar thoughts and beliefs of a perfectionist.
It's very important for you to question all such thoughts and work with them.
How? It will be helpful to continue keeping a diary of automatic thoughts, where you can identify these ideas, check them against reality, and give them a rational response.

quote.text: I've missed more than 9000 shots in my career. I've lost almost 300 games. 26 times, I've been trusted to take the game winning shot and missed. I've failed over and over and over again in my life. And that is why I succeed.
quote.author: Michael Jordan

texts: The following questions can help with reality testing (cognitive restructuring):
What evidence do I have that supports this thought or belief?
Is this thought helpful?
Are there other ways I can think about this situation or about myself?
Am I blaming myself unnecessarily?
What or who else contributed to this situation?
Is this really under my control?
Am I adhering to unfounded or double standards?
Is this a realistic expectation?
These questions are aimed at checking a belief, confirming it, clarifying it or refuting it, and formulating an alternative belief.

Ask yourself: what if I do it perfectly, then what? And if I don't do it perfectly, then what? Try to figure out what's behind your perfectionism. Are you afraid of rejection? Are you afraid of public ridicule? Is there a thirst for recognition behind perfectionism?
When you understand what's behind perfectionism, ask yourself if you're really addressing these fears and needs with it.

Well, you wrote the report perfectly, submitted it, and then what? Now you're not afraid at all that people will turn away from you? Well, you performed perfectly, they applauded you, and that's it, are these ovations from a crowd of strangers enough for you?
Most likely, your answer is negative. You achieved the ideal, experienced bliss for a while, and then back into this race again.
Get rid of black and white thinking
Perfectionists often think in categories of «all or nothing», «success or failure», «do it perfectly or don't start at all».

Such an approach is unrealistic. Look around and ask yourself how many things in the world fit the category of «all or nothing». Are your walls perfectly clean? Or is there at least some dirt on them?
Do you know a person who is absolutely calm and confident? Does your favorite actress possess perfect beauty, or does she still have flaws?
In life, rarely anything is achieved without mistakes and failures.
No one is born a master - we learn, try, make mistakes, and gradually improve.

So allow yourself to be imperfect, to do something incompletely, to make mistakes. Mistakes are not enemies, but helpers on the path to success. Remember the saying more often: «He who makes no mistakes makes nothing».
It's not worth immediately giving up all ideals - this could be too drastic a change.
Act gradually.
Start small: choose one, the least significant ideal and try to give it up. Observe the result.
The world won't collapse if you don't do something perfectly. Your loved ones won't turn away from you, you won't become a terrible person.
Most likely, you'll cope with the imperfect result much easier than it seems. Remember that one experiment doesn't give a complete picture. Consistency is needed.
Every week or month, give up one ideal and observe the reaction. Listen to yourself and move at a pace comfortable for you.
Keep an achievement diary

Write down both big and small, significant and not so significant successes. Every day. Perfectionism loves defeats, and when you once again tell yourself: «I never succeed at anything», immediately after that open your notebook and read how much you've already succeeded at.
Another way to overcome perfectionism is to focus on the process.
This means that when evaluating an action, you focus more on the process rather than the result.

Imagine you're a driver and every day you drive from point A to point B. On some days, the traffic lights are mostly green, and you quickly reach your destination. On other days, you constantly hit red lights, get stuck in traffic jams, and the trip takes much longer.
Your driving skills don't change, so why not feel equally satisfied with the work you do every day? Try to look at things in a new way, without trying to do your work or some action perfectly.
For example, as a student, you can set the following process-oriented goals:
attend classes;
listen attentively and take notes;
ask relevant questions;
dedicate a certain amount of time to each subject;
re-read the notes taken during classes every two to three weeks.
You can control all these processes, so success is guaranteed. The final grade or result, on the other hand, is not under your control.
The outcome depends on how your teacher feels that day, how well other students performed, what criteria they apply, etc.
Use the «greed technique»
It's based on the simple fact that most of us strive to be perfect in order to succeed in life. It might not have occurred to you that you could be much more successful if you lower your standards.
For example, once a famous psychotherapist spent more than two years writing his first scientific article.

It was excellent and was published. But during the same time, his colleagues wrote and published significantly more equally good works. So he wondered what was better: to have one article with 98% «perfection» or 10 articles with 80% «perfection»?
In the second case, productivity would be higher, and he could have been ahead of his colleagues. This realization prompted the psychotherapist to soften his standards.
As a result, his productivity increased, and his job satisfaction grew.
Completing several tasks well can be more effective than fixating on creating a perfect product with a lot of stress.
Formulate new beliefs
Working on beliefs involves recognizing them, thinking through their consequences, finding their sources, and ends with formulating new, alternative beliefs.
Essentially, our task is to help «normalize» various manifestations of «imperfection» (mistakes, failures), to help accept the idea of one's own imperfection and the imperfection of other people.
Give up beliefs like:
I/others/the world must be perfect
If it's not perfect, then it's bad
If it's bad, then others will turn away from me/won't recognize me/I won't cope
Instead, use new beliefs and phrases.
I'm not perfect, but I:
Learn and grow
Am good enough
Deserve love and respect, even if I'm not perfect
Others are not perfect, but they:
Are also people, with their strengths and weaknesses
Won't always approve of me, and that's okay
I make mistakes, but this gives me the opportunity to:
Learn from my mistakes
Become better
Show resilience and not give up
Write down your new beliefs and implement them in your life.
You can write them on a sticky note and attach it to the refrigerator, enter them in the notes on your phone, or create an image with them and set it as your desktop background.
Read these statements every day, at least once, better more. This will help you reprogram your thoughts and replace unhealthy beliefs with more adaptive ones.
Fortunately, perfectionism is not a sentence.

With small steps - on your own or under the guidance of a specialist - you can bring perfectionism to a healthy level. For this, it is necessary to learn to love yourself unconditionally and take care of yourself daily.
